question: How has Nvidia's data center revenue changed over the past year?
ground_truth: Nvidia's data center revenue has grown significantly, driven by AI GPU demand. The segment has shown consistent triple-digit growth rates throughout FY2024-2025.
generated_answer:
Atomic Facts with Citations
• Q4 2025 data center revenue: $35.6B (YoY +93% / QoQ +16%) [C1]
• Q3 2025 data center revenue: $30.8B (YoY +112% / QoQ +17%) [C2]
• Q2 2025 data center revenue: $26.3B (YoY +154% / QoQ +16%) [C3]
• Q2 2026 data center revenue: $41.1B (YoY +56% / QoQ +5%) [C6]
• Q3 2024 data center revenue: $14.5B (YoY +279% / QoQ +41%) [C9]
• Q3 2026 networking revenue: $8.2B (YoY +162%) [C5]
• Q2 2026 networking revenue: $7.3B [C7]
• Trailing twelve months data center revenue calculation: Not found in provided sources
 Final Answer
Data Center Revenue: $35.6B (YoY +93% / QoQ +16%) [C1]
NVDA's data center segment demonstrates exceptional growth momentum across recent quarters. Q4 2025 delivered $35.6B in data center revenue, accelerating 93% year-over-year and 16% quarter-over-quarter [C1]. The segment maintained strong sequential growth throughout fiscal 2025: Q3 at $30.8B (+112% YoY / +17% QoQ) [C2] and Q2 at $26.3B (+154% YoY / +16% QoQ) [C3].
Looking forward, Q2 2026 data center revenue reached $41.1B, growing 56% year-over-year but moderating to 5% quarter-over-quarter [C6]. Networking revenue within data center surged to $8.2B in Q3 2026, up 162% year-over-year [C5].
The growth trajectory reflects strong demand for Hopper H100/H200 platforms and early Blackwell ramp, with sequential quarterly increases consistently in the mid-to-high teens percentage range through fiscal 2025 [C1][C2][C3].
Trailing twelve months data center revenue total: Not found in provided sources.

However, there are some concerns: 1) The answer refers to quarters as 'Q4 2025', 'Q3 2025', etc., but the context chunks don't explicitly label which fiscal quarter each belongs to - the answer appears to be inferring this. 2) The citation [C6] for Q2 2026 data center revenue ($41.1B) actually corresponds to Chunk 4, not Chunk 6. 3) The citation [C9] for Q3 2024 data center revenue ($14.5B) refers to Chunk 7, which doesn't specify the quarter as Q3 2024. 4) The citation [C7] for Q2 2026 networking revenue ($7.3B) correctly references Chunk 9 content. 5) The answer correctly acknowledges that trailing twelve months calculation is 'Not found in provided sources.' The core financial figures are present in the context, but the quarter labeling and some citation numbering appears to be inferred or misaligned rather than directly stated in the context.

The ground truth states that Nvidia's data center revenue has grown significantly with 'consistent triple-digit growth rates throughout FY2024-2025.' The generated answer provides specific quarterly data confirming this: Q3 2024 showed +279% YoY, Q2 2025 showed +154% YoY, Q3 2025 showed +112% YoY, and Q4 2025 showed +93% YoY. While Q4 2025's 93% is technically not triple-digit, the answer demonstrates that triple-digit growth was indeed consistent through most of the period mentioned. The generated answer provides substantially more detail with specific revenue figures and growth percentages that are consistent with the ground truth's claim of significant growth driven by AI GPU demand (mentioning Hopper H100/H200 platforms and Blackwell). The answer is factually aligned with the ground truth's assertions.

metadata.text:
NVIDIA Announces Financial Results for Second Quarter Fiscal 2026
Revenue of $46.7 billion, up 6% from Q1 and up 56% from a year ago
Data Center revenue of $41.1 billion, up 5% from Q1 and up 56% from a year ago
Blackwell Data Center revenue grew 17% sequentially
August 27, 2025
NVIDIA Announces Financial Results for Second Quarter Fiscal 2026
NVIDIA (NASDAQ: NVDA) today reported revenue for the second quarter ended July 27, 2025, of $46.7 billion, up 6% from the previous quarter and up 56% from a year ago. NVIDIA’s Blackwell Data Center revenue grew 17% sequentially. There were no H20 sales to China-based customers in the second quarter.

in every cloud. CSPs appreciate the broad adoption of NVIDIA and are growing their NVIDIA capacity, given the high demand. NVIDIA H200 platform began ramping in Q2, shipping to large CSPs, consumer Internet and enterprise company. The NVIDIA H200 builds upon the strength of our Hopper architecture and offering over 40% more memory bandwidth compared to the H100. Our Data Center revenue in China grew sequentially in Q2 and a significant contributor to our Data Center revenue. As a percentage of total Data Center revenue, it remains below levels seen prior to the imposition of export controls. We continue to expect the China market to be very competitive going forward.

34% sequentially and up more than 200% year-on-year and well above our outlook of $16 billion. Starting with data center. The continued ramp of the NVIDIA HGX platform based on our Hopper Tensor Core GPU architecture, along with InfiniBand end-to-end networking, drove record revenue of $14.5 billion, up 41% sequentially and up 279% year-on-year. NVIDIA HGX with InfiniBand together are essentially the reference architecture for AI supercomputers and data center infrastructures. Some of the most exciting generative AI applications are built and run on NVIDIA, including Adobe, Firefly, ChatGPT, Microsoft 365 Copilot, CoAssist, Now Assist with ServiceNow and Zoom AI Companion. Our data center compute revenue quadrupled from last year and networking revenue nearly tripled.
